member.summary: Attribute to apply an authorization policy and/or roles to a graph, field or query argument. Marks the graph, field or query argument as requiring authentication even if no policies or roles are specified. This attribute mimics AuthorizeAttribute from ASP.NET Core so it is something people are likely used to, if they do any web programming in C#.

member.name: T:GraphQL.ValueConverter
member.summary:
This class provides value conversions between objects of different types. Conversions are registered in a static thread safe dictionary and are used for all schemas in the application.
Each ScalarGraphType calls ConvertTo method to return correct value type from its ParseValue method. Also conversions may be useful in advanced GetArgument use cases when deserialization from the values dictionary to the complex input argument is required.

Throws a if there is no conversion registered; conversion functions may throw other exceptions
Returns an object of the specified type and whose value is equivalent to the specified object.
Throws a if there is no conversion registered; conversion functions may throw other exceptions
If a conversion delegate was registered, converts an object to the specified type and returns ; returns if no conversion delegate is registered.
Conversion delegates may throw exceptions if the conversion was unsuccessful

member.summary: Called when the document begins executing, passing in a delegate to continue execution.
member.remarks: can be used to resolve other services from the dependency injection framework.

member.name: P:GraphQL.DI.IConfigureExecution.SortOrder
member.summary:
Determines the order of the registered instances; the lowest order executes first; instances with the same value execute in the same order they were registered, assuming the dependency injection provider returns instances in the order they were registered.
The default sort order of configurations are as follows:
100: Option configurations -- 'Add' calls such as AddValidationRule, and ConfigureExecutionOptions calls
200: Execution configurations -- 'Use' calls such as UseApolloTracing, and ConfigureExecution calls

member.name: M:GraphQL.Execution.ExecutionStrategy.ShouldIncludeNode(GraphQL.Execution.ExecutionContext,GraphQLParser.AST.IHasDirectivesNode)
member.summary:
Examines @skip and @include directives for a node and returns a value indicating if the node should be included or not.
Note: Neither @skip nor @include has precedence over the other. In the case that both the @skip and @include directives are provided on the same field or fragment, it must be queried only if the @skip condition is and the @include condition is . Stated conversely, the field or fragment must not be queried if either the @skip condition is or the @include condition is .

member.summary:
Before execution, the selection set is converted to a grouped field set by calling CollectFields(). Each entry in the grouped field set is a list of fields that share a response key (the alias if defined, otherwise the field name). This ensures all fields with the same response key included via referenced fragments are executed at the same time.
and

member.name: M:GraphQL.Execution.SubscriptionExecutionStrategy.ExecuteAsync(GraphQL.Execution.ExecutionContext)
member.summary:
Executes a GraphQL subscription request and returns the result. The result consists of one or more streams of GraphQL responses, returned within . No serializable is directly returned unless an error has occurred. This relates more to the protocol in use (defined in the transport layer) than the response here.
Keep in mind that if a scoped context is passed into , and if it is disposed after the initial execution, node executions of subsequent data events will contain the disposed instance and hence be unusable.
If scoped services are needed, it is recommended to utilize the ScopedSubscriptionExecutionStrategy class from the GraphQL.MicrosoftDI package, which will create a service scope during processing of data events.

member.name: T:GraphQL.IDocumentExecuter
member.summary:
Processes an entire GraphQL request, given an input GraphQL request string. This is intended to be called by user code to process a query.
Typical implementation starts metrics if enabled (see Metrics), relies on IDocumentBuilder to parse the query and IDocumentValidator to validate it. Then it executes document listeners if attached, selects an execution strategy, and executes the query via IExecutionStrategy. Unhandled exceptions are handled as appropriate for the selected options.

member.name: M:GraphQL.GraphQLBuilderExtensions.AddGraphTypes(GraphQL.DI.IGraphQLBuilder)
member.summary:
Scans the calling assembly for classes that implement and registers them as transients within the dependency injection framework. A transient lifetime ensures they are only instantiated once each time the schema is built. If the schema is a scoped schema, the graph types will effectively be scoped graph types. If the schema is a singleton schema, the graph types will effectively be singleton graph types.
Also registers , , , , , , and as generic types.

member.name: M:GraphQL.GraphQLBuilderExtensions.UseMiddleware``1(GraphQL.DI.IGraphQLBuilder,System.Boolean,GraphQL.DI.ServiceLifetime)
member.summary: Registers with the dependency injection framework as both and . If is , installs the middleware by configuring schema construction to call Use with an instance of the middleware pulled from dependency injection. Transient and singleton lifetimes are supported. Transient is default, and causes the middleware lifetime to match that of the schema. This effectively provides singleton middleware if using a singleton schema, and scoped middleware if using a scoped schema. Specifying a singleton lifetime is also permissible, providing a benefit if the schema has a scoped lifetime.
member.remarks: If is , do not separately install the middleware within your schema constructor or the middleware may be registered twice within the schema.

member.name: M:GraphQL.GraphQLBuilderExtensions.UseMiddleware``1(GraphQL.DI.IGraphQLBuilder,System.Func{System.IServiceProvider,GraphQL.Types.ISchema,System.Boolean},GraphQL.DI.ServiceLifetime)
member.summary: Registers with the dependency injection framework as both and . Calls the delegate during schema construction, and if , installs the middleware by configuring schema construction to call Use with an instance of the middleware pulled from dependency injection. Transient and singleton lifetimes are supported. Transient is default, and causes the middleware lifetime to match that of the schema. This effectively provides singleton middleware if using a singleton schema, and scoped middleware if using a scoped schema. Specifying a singleton lifetime is also permissible, providing a benefit if the schema has a scoped lifetime.
member.remarks: Do not separately install the middleware within your schema constructor or the middleware may be registered twice within the schema.

member.name: T:GraphQL.ExperimentalIntrospectionFeaturesMode
member.summary: A way to use experimental features.

member.name: F:GraphQL.ExperimentalIntrospectionFeaturesMode.ExecutionOnly
member.summary: Allow experimental features only for client queries but not for standard introspection request. This means that the client, in response to a standard introspection request, receives a standard response without any new fields and types. However, client CAN make requests to the server using the new fields and types. This mode is needed in order to bypass the problem of tools such as GraphQL Playground, Voyager, GraphiQL that require a standard response to an introspection request and refuse to work correctly if there are any unknown fields or types in the response.

member.name: F:GraphQL.ExperimentalIntrospectionFeaturesMode.IntrospectionAndExecution
member.summary: Allow experimental features for both standard introspection query and client queries. This means that the client, in response to a standard introspection request, receives a response augmented with the new fields and types. Client can make requests to the server using the new fields and types.

By default enabled.

member.name: P:GraphQL.GlobalSwitches.EnableReadDescriptionFromXmlDocumentation
member.summary:
Enables or disables setting default values for 'description' from XML documentation.
By default disabled.

member.name: F:GraphQL.GlobalSwitches.NameValidation
member.summary:
Gets or sets current validation delegate. By default this delegate validates all names according to the GraphQL specification.
Setting this delegate allows you to use names not conforming to the specification, for example 'enum-member'. Only change it when absolutely necessary. This is typically only overridden when implementing a custom that fixes names, making them spec-compliant.
Keep in mind that regardless of this setting, names are validated upon schema initialization, after being processed by the . This is due to the fact that the parser cannot parse incoming queries with invalid characters in the names, so the resulting member would become unusable.

member.name: P:GraphQL.GlobalSwitches.UseDeclaringTypeNames
member.summary:
Specifies whether to use the names of parent (declaring) types in case of nested graph types when calculating default graph type name.
By default disabled.

member.name: P:GraphQL.GlobalSwitches.GlobalAttributes
member.summary:
A collection of global instances which are applied while AutoRegisteringObjectGraphType, AutoRegisteringInputObjectGraphType, EnumerationGraphType, ResolveDelegate or the schema builder is building graph types, field definitions, arguments, or similar.
The collection is not thread-safe; instances should be added prior to schema initialization.

summary.para: A field resolver returns an object for a given field within a graph.
The property defines the field resolver to be used for the field.
Typically an instance of FuncFieldResolver is created when code needs to execute within the field resolver - typically by calling FieldBuilder.Resolve or FieldBuilder.ResolveAsync.
When mapping fields to source object properties via Field(x => x.Name), ExpressionFieldResolver is used.
When a field resolver is not defined, such as with Field("Name"), the static instance of is used.

member.name: T:GraphQL.Resolvers.ISourceStreamResolver
member.summary: Returns an for a field. The provides a sequence of event notifications (aka 'an event stream') to the subscription execution engine, which will resolve child fields using the event data as the source. Then the resolved graph is returned to the client, and the process repeats for further event notifications.

summary.para: Dynamically creates the necessary delegate in runtime to get the property/method value of the specified type.
Example:

So resulting Func will be generated as {x => Convert(Convert(x, Person).Age, Object)}
1. First, the input parameter 'x' is converted from the object to a specific type.
2. The required property or method is extracted from casted value.
3. Then result is converted again to the object and returned from the method.

Property/method name.

member.name: T:GraphQL.Types.ArgumentInformation
member.summary:
Contains information pertaining to a method parameter in preparation for building an expression or query argument for it.
If is set, a query argument will not be added and the expression will be used to build the method resolver.
If not, a query argument will be generated and added to the field; the field resolver will use the argument's value to populate the method parameter.

member.name: P:GraphQL.Types.ArgumentInformation.Expression
member.summary:
Gets or sets a delegate in the form of a to be used to populate this method argument while building the field resolver.
If not set, a query argument will be added to the field and the argument's value will be used to populate the method argument while building the field resolver.
The delegate must be of the type Expression<Func<, TParameterType>> where TParameterType matches ParameterInfo.ParameterType.

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.ArgumentInformation.SetDelegate``1(System.Func{GraphQL.IResolveFieldContext,``0})
member.summary:
Sets a delegate to be used to populate this method argument while building the field resolver. An expression is generated that calls and stored within .
The delegate must be of the type Func<, > where matches ParameterInfo.ParameterType.

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.ArgumentInformation.ApplyAttributes
member.summary: Applies attributes pulled from the ParameterInfo onto this instance. Also scans the parameter's owning module and assembly for globally-applied attributes.

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.ArgumentInformation.ConstructQueryArgument
member.summary:
Builds a query argument or expression from this instance.
If a query argument is returned, it will be added to the arguments list of the field type.
If an expression is returned, it will be used to populate the method argument within the field resolver; if not, the query argument's value will be used to populate the method argument within the field resolver.
The default implementation will return either a or instance; not both. It is possible to return both, in which case the query argument will be added to the field and the expression will be used to populate the method argument within the field resolver. You cannot return for both the query argument and expression.

Configures query arguments and a field resolver for the specified , overwriting any existing configuration within , and .
For fields and properties, no query arguments are added and the field resolver simply pulls the appropriate member from .

member.summary:
Used to specify the minimum and/or maximum length for an input field or argument.
When applied to argument or input field, this directive itself does not check anything. It only declares the necessary requirements and these requirements will be visible in introspection if ExperimentalFeatures.AppliedDirectives feature is enabled on schema. Use validation rule if you want to enable checking for the length of arguments and input fields.

member.name: T:GraphQL.Types.ISchema
member.summary:
The schema for the GraphQL request. Contains references to the 'query', 'mutation', and 'subscription' base graph types.
Also allows for adding custom directives, additional graph types, and custom value converters.
only requires the Query property to be set; although commonly the Mutation and/or Subscription properties are also set.

Initializes the schema. Called by before validating or executing the request.
Note that middleware cannot be applied once the schema has been initialized. See .
This method should be safe to be called from multiple threads simultaneously.

member.name: P:GraphQL.Types.ISchema.FieldMiddleware
member.summary: Note that field middlewares from this property apply only to an uninitialized schema. If the schema is initialized then adding additional middleware through the builder does nothing. The schema is initialized (if not yet) at the beginning of the first call to .ExecuteAsync. However, you can also apply middlewares at any time in runtime using SchemaTypes.ApplyMiddleware method.

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.ScalarGraphType.Serialize(System.Object)
member.summary:
Result (output) coercion. It takes the result of a resolver and converts it into an appropriate value for the output result. In other words it transforms a scalar from its server-side representation to a representation suitable for the client.
Since GraphQL specifies no response format, Serialize is not responsible for preparing the scalar for transport to the client. It is only responsible for generating an object which can eventually be serialized by some transport-focused API.
This method should handle a value of , but may throw an exception if is an invalid internal scalar representation.
member.param: Resolved value (internal scalar representation). May be .
member.returns: The returned value of a the result coercion is part of the overall execution result. Normally this value is a primitive value like String or Integer to make it easy for the serialization layer. For complex types like a Date or Money scalar this involves formatting the value. Thus, the returned value for some scalars by their nature may already have a string value and it is impossible (or rather difficult) to change that value by the serialization layer. Returning is valid.

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.ScalarGraphType.ParseLiteral(GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLValue)
member.summary:
Literal input coercion. It takes an abstract syntax tree (AST) element from a schema definition or query and converts it into an appropriate internal value. In other words it transforms a scalar from its client-side representation as an argument to its server-side representation. Input coercion may not only return primitive values like String but rather complex ones when appropriate.
This method must handle a value of .
This method SHOULD be overridden by descendants.
member.param: AST value node. Must not be , but may be .
member.returns: Internal scalar representation. Returning is valid.

member.summary: Parses a according to the GraphQL specification, throwing a conversion error if the value is outside the range of a .

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.ScalarGraphType.ParseValue(System.Object)
member.summary:
Value input coercion. Argument values can not only provided via GraphQL syntax inside a query, but also via variable. It transforms a scalar from its client-side representation as a variable to its server-side representation.
Parsing for arguments and variables are handled separately because while arguments must always be expressed in GraphQL query syntax, variable format is transport-specific (usually JSON).
This method must handle a value of .
member.param: Runtime object from variables. May be .
member.returns: Internal scalar representation. Returning is valid.

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.ScalarGraphType.CanParseLiteral(GraphQLParser.AST.GraphQLValue)
member.summary:
Checks for literal input coercion possibility. It takes an abstract syntax tree (AST) element from a schema definition or query and checks if it can be converted into an appropriate internal value. In other words it checks if a scalar can be converted from its client-side representation as an argument to its server-side representation.
This method can be overridden to validate input values without directly getting those values, i.e. without boxing.
This method must return when passed a node.
member.param: AST value node. Must not be , but may be .

Parsing for arguments and variables are handled separately because while arguments must always be expressed in GraphQL query syntax, variable format is transport-specific (usually JSON).
This method can be overridden to validate input values without directly getting those values, i.e. without boxing.

member.name: M:GraphQL.Types.Schema.System#IServiceProvider#GetService(System.Type)
member.summary:
Gets the service object of the specified type. Schema itself acts as a service provider used to create objects, such as graph types, requested by the schema.
Note that most objects are created during schema initialization, which then have the same lifetime as the schema's lifetime.
Other types created by the service provider may include directive visitors, middlewares, validation rules, and name converters, among others.
Explicit implementation of the method makes this method less visible to the calling code, which reduces the likelihood of using it as so called ServiceLocator anti-pattern. However, in some advanced scenarios this may be necessary.
member.param: An object that specifies the type of service object to get.
member.returns: A service object of type or if there is no service object of type serviceType.

member.summary: Computes the Damerau-Levenshtein Distance between two strings, represented as arrays of integers, where each integer represents the code point of a character in the source string. Includes an optional threshold which can be used to indicate the maximum allowable distance. http://stackoverflow.com/a/9454016/279764
member.param: An array of the code points of the first string
An array of the code points of the second string
Maximum allowable distance
member.returns: Int.MaxValue if threshold exceeded; otherwise the Damerau-Levenshtein distance between the strings

member.name: T:GraphQL.Validation.Rules.OverlappingFieldsCanBeMerged
member.summary:
Overlapping fields are mergable:
If multiple field selections with the same response names are encountered during execution, the field and arguments to execute and the resulting value should be unambiguous. Therefore any two field selections which might both be encountered for the same object are only valid if they are equivalent.
